data.text: Index
Appendix 1: Dexmedetomidine Infusion Flow Chart Appendix 2:Dexmedetomidine Monograph Appendix 3: Preliminary Equality Analysis

Dexmedetomidine is an alpha 2 agonist licensed in the UK for ICU patients to maintain sedation at a level not deeper than arousal in response to verbal stimulation (RASS -3 to 0). It has sedative, analgesic and anaesthetic sparing effects.
Maintain sedation in ICU patients at a level responsive to verbal stimulation (RASS -3 to 0);
ICU patients with Alcohol Withdrawal Syndrome (AWS);
ICU patients with hyperactive delirium with a history of alcohol consumption;
ICU patients who are difficult to wean from ventilation to extubation due to delirium.
Second or third degree heart block;
Uncontrolled hypotension;
Acute cerebrovascular disorders;
Previous allergy to alpha 2 agonists.
Hepatic Impairment
No data in pregnancy and breastfeeding
Hypovolaemia
Hypotension (25%);
Hypertension (15%);
Bradycardia (13%)3.
Dexmedetomidine is available in the UK as ‘Dexdor®' (Orion Pharma); as 100- micrograms/ml concentrate;
Dexmedetomidine should be diluted to 8 microgram/ml for infusion;
Do not co-administer with any other drug infusion or fluid that may be bolused.
Central distribution T/ 6 minutes, terminal elimination T/ 1.9-2.5 hours;
Metabolised in the liver to inactive metabolites.
Dexmedetomidine infusion to be commenced only on the advice of an ICU Consultant.
Infusion may be administered via peripheral or central venous access.
Infusion doses are based on patient's actual body weight.
Commence infusion at 0.7mcg/kg/hour and titrate infusion by 0.2mcg/kg/hour every 15 minutes to a maximum rate of 1.4 mcg/kg/hour, to achieve target sedation level.
If HR <60 reduce infusion rate by 0.2 mcg/kg/hour.
Reduced maintenance doses should be consider in patients with hepatic impairment.
Reduce hypnotic infusion (propofol) by 25-50% every  minutes until off.
Reduce opioid infusion rate by 25-50% every 60 minutes titrated to an acceptable pain score.
For patients with AWS continue with usual benzodiazepine regimen.
Do not alter the infusion rate of Dexmedetomidine during routine daily sedation holds.

When sedation is no longer required Dexmedetomidine infusion may be stopped or if preferred after prolonged treatment the infusion may be reduced by 0.4 mcg/kg/min to 0.2 mcg/kg/min and run until infusion is complete.
All medical and nursing staff are to ensure that their knowledge, competencies and skills are up to date.
During induction, staff will receive instruction on current policies and guidelines and how to access them.
This guideline will be published on the Trust website.
Equality Impact Assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals (refer to Appendix 1).
APPENDIX 1:
Dexmedetomidine Infusion Flow Chart
Find actual body weight to calculate starting dose of 0.7mcg/kg/hour DO NOT use loading dose [range 0.2 to 1.4mcg/kg/hour]
Dexdor® concentrate must be diluted prior to use. Administer as a diluted IV infusion via peripheral or central line using syringe driver / infusion pump
* Use either sodium chloride 0.9% or glucose 5% to dilute dexdor® to concentration 8mcg/mL
Run for 15 minutes then assess
No patient for desired level of sedation  Yes
RASS score achieved ?
Titrate dose stepwise at 15 minute
intervals using 0.2 mcg/kg/hr to
achieve desired RASS score within the  Wean other sedation by 25 – 50% per hour
first hour. Continue cardiac monitoring
Continue other sedation until dexdor®  Reduce infusion rate if bradycardia
reaches target effect or hypotension occur
NB: max dose 1.4mcg/kg/hr
To stop dexmedetomidine:
Reduce infusion rate stepwise by 0.4mcg/kg/hr to 0.2mcg/kg/hr increments
over a few hours and run until finished.
If no withdrawal symptoms after 30 minutes, simply allow infusion to run out Note: can be continued during and after extubation
